title: ould you be flexitarian?
intro: Could you eat less meat and adopt a diet based on vegetables and fruit to help save the environment? Neil and Catherine talk about a new diet, known as flexitarianism, and teach you new vocabulary.
this_week_question: All peppers are in the same food group. What group is that? Are peppers:
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a diet based on eating mostly plant-based food and only occasionally eating meat
doing something for  reasons means doing it as a moral choice because you believe it is the right thing to do
impressive and out of the ordinary
a food that we really like but we only have it rarely because it’s expensive, rare and/or bad for our health

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English I'm Neil.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: And I'm Catherine.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Catherine, are you flexitarian ?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: No, I’m not really religious, Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It’s not a religion! It’s a diet. It means mainly eating plant-based foods and only occasionally eating meat.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Oh, I see, sorry – er, well, I don't eat too much meat so I'm kind of on the way to flexitarianism.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Some people don’t eat meat for ethical reasons. That means that for them it’s wrong to eat meat, it’s wrong that animals should be killed for our food. But one of the reasons for being flexitarian and only eating meat once in a while is for the benefit of the planet. According to a recent report, being flexitarian is healthier for the individual but can also help to fight climate change. Before we look in more detail at this topic, a question: Do you like peppers, Catherine?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Yes, I do. Is that correct?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's not the quiz question! But this is. All peppers are in the same food group. What group is it? Are peppers:
Any ideas?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: This one sounds like a trick question - but I think it’s obviously vegetables. Yep?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, you’ll have to wait a bit to find out. I'll have the answer later in the programme. Now, Dr Marco Springmann is from the University of Oxford and was one of the lead authors of a major report that looked at the global food system and how it affects the climate. On the BBC Today programme he talked about what changes would be needed. Does he mention just one thing?

transcript.author: Dr Marco Springmann
transcript.text: We really found that a combination of measures would be needed to stay within environmental limits and those include changes towards healthier more plant-based diets, ambitious technological improvements and changes in farming management, and a reduction of food loss and waste.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So did he mention just one thing, Catherine?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: No, not at all. He said that there would need to be a combination of measures which means 'a variety of different actions' including moving to a plant-based diet, developing technology, changing the way we farm and wasting less food.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: He described the need for ambitious technological improvements. Ambitious here means the developments will have to be 'impressive, above the ordinary and not simple'. Dr Springmann was asked if we had to completely remove meat from the food that we eat to be healthy. What was his recommendation?

transcript.author: Dr Marco Springmann
transcript.text: Well, we looked … we surveyed the literature on what a healthy diet is and according to that, if you treat it as a luxury , it’s probably OK but you shouldn’t have more than one serving of red meat, which includes beef and pork, per week. So the more plant-based you go, the healthier and the lower an environmental impact it probably will be.

transcript.author: BBC Today programme presenter
transcript.text: And lamb is just the same…

transcript.author: Dr Marco Springmann
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So do we need to cut out meat entirely?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: He says that while a plant-based diet is certainly healthier, you could still have some red meat but only once a week.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, he said think of it as a luxury . A luxury food is one that we really enjoy but don’t eat very often – perhaps because it’s very expensive or rare.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Or delicious but very bad for us. We eat it as a treat but not every day. Springmann says we should think of red meat in the same way. It shouldn’t be a regular part of our diet.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: How did he come to this opinion? Did they just make it up themselves because it sounds like a good idea?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Not at all, Neil. He said that they surveyed the literature . This means that as part of their report they studied different scientific research that had previously been published. Their advice is based on the evidence of those research papers.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. Now the answer to our quiz question. I asked to what food group do peppers belong. Was it:

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: I said b) vegetables.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh dear, good try but not right, thanks for playing. The answer is a) fruit.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Fruit? Really?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. A fruit is the part of plant that contains the seeds – so peppers, like tomatoes, pumpkins, avocados and olives are actually fruit. Well done if you got that one right. Now, our vocabulary. Our first word is flexitarian . This is the term for a diet that is mainly plant-based but can include meat occasionally.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Our next word is ethical . This is in the context of choosing not to eat meat. Some people are vegetarian because they don’t like meat, some because they want a healthier diet and some for ethical reasons. This means that their choice is because they feel it is the right thing to do.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The next phrase was a combination of measures . This means 'taking different actions to achieve something', not just doing one thing.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: We then had ambitious . If a person is ambitious , it means that they 'want to get on in life and be successful', but ambitious can also be used to describe a plan or achievement which is 'impressive and above the ordinary'.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The next phrase was to survey the literature . This means to 'study and analyse the different scientific research on a particular subject'.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: And finally we had luxury . When talking about food, a luxury is something that we only eat occasionally as a special treat because it’s expensive or unhealthy but delicious.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I’m off for a plate of delicious vegetables. Please join us next time and why not check us out on your favourite social media platform, on our app and of course the website bbclearningenglish.com? Goodbye.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Bye!
